Express still sends default doctype in view options to jade.
tested in express 2.4.2

body: Per issue #739.

title: Tentative support for node 0.5
body:
Any chance for supporting node 0.5 in the npm package?

I have been using express with 0.5.0-pre for a while now as I experiment with SPDY support.  Admittedly, I have not explored the full breadth of express, but all of my sample apps have worked fine.

title: Docs don't mention that 'status' is a special parameter for res.render
With showStack:true, any errors generated after response.send crash node.js
body:
Here is a minimal repro server:

``` coffeescript
express = require 'express'

server = express.createServer()
server.use(express.errorHandler({ showStack: true }));

server.get( '/', (request, response) ->
    response.send "text"
    x.y = z
    )

server.listen 8080
```

When you attempt to hit localhost:8080 you will crash the server with a massive stack trace, which boils down the fact that the response is already sent so the errorHandler can't change it.  The fact that the response can't be recalled is fine, but it shouldn't down the server imo.

title: res.json does not handle JSONP in 2.4.0
body:
res.json does not return JSONP output (at all) if the callback parameter is present.

It would be nice if it just replicated the functionality from res.send in this regard.

Default res.cookie() and res.clearCookie() path to "home" setting
body:
I have mixed feelings about this, as it's potentially confusing, though I think it's less confusing than people getting messed up and thinking it _is_ the default. also it makes the api look better for the common use-case. so:

```
 res.cookie('name', 'val', { path: '/' })
```

would just become:

```
 res.cookie('name', 'val')
```

and by defaulting this to the "home" setting, those who mount express at say `/store`, will then be implicitly altering this default

body:
Make an example that shows how one would load a dynamic javascript or css file.  For example:

Let's say I want to load the minimal amount of external resources and then if a person moves to a specific page I add on javascript or css files that the new page will need.

title: Partials don't return strings, cause res.send() to be called more than once
body:
Here's a reduced example of my situation: https://github.com/isaacs/express-partial-break
1. There's a dynamicHelper function that does `return res.partial("flashMessages.ejs", options)`.  This is a handy bit of logic that shows a message if there's a message to show, and clears out the messages for that session.  (In the reduced example, it's just a single global object.)
2. A few different views do `<%- flashMessages() %>` to call the dynamicHelper function and spit out the results of the partial.
3. Since the partial gets run without a cb, it calls res.send().  I think this is a mistake.
4. Since the headers have already been sent (when it entered the initial res.render() call that loaded the template that called the dynamic helper that called res.partial), this makes node blow up in a huge mushroom-cloud of stack traces.

The optimum solution here seems to be a way for me to call res.partial and get the results as a string.  I suspect that doing res.send in a res.partial call is almost always going to be a problem, because partials by their very nature are not a full response, but only part of one.  If no cb is provided, then res.partial should return the partial string, instead of sending it.

title: Dynamic Helpers that can act as functions
body: Dynamic helpers are great because they allow access to the req and res objects, but I don't (always) like how they "become the local variable it is associated with."  Besides making a static helper that requires the view pass in request and response, is there a way to create functions that can see these objects?

title: Bug: CLI `Express app` does not auto-support npm 1.x
body: CLI created express apps are missing an `npm link express` and the folder to contain it `node_modules`. This is basically a bug because new express apps simply don't work without these extra two steps.

title: Add support to res.sendfile() for non-GET request
body: currently it uses connect's `connect.static.send()` which checks for **GET**, so we need to remove that (for express only) with an option, and pause the request data

title: Express server delayed recovery after connect-redis reconnects
body:
Here's the steps to take to see this issue I am having when the connect-redis client temporarily loses its connection:

1) Start redis database used by connect-redis module to store sessions
2) Start express server
3) Run test client to show that express server can handle http requests
4) Shutdown redis database
5) Now, the express server is unable to handle connections (as expected) and the client "hangs" before timing out.
6) Turn Redis Database back on.
7) Note that redis client used by connect-redis immediately regains connection.  (I see this because I captured the "connect" event on the node redis client.)
8) Run test client again and for several minutes, requests continue to hang
9) Eventually after a few minutes, the express server can handle connections again.

Its as if there is some cache that needs to "timeout" before the state can be reset, but I don't know.  The expected behavior of course is that as soon as the at our Redis database is back up, Express should be able to start handling requests again.

Any ideas?

title: Consider each call to app.get() etc as it's own middleware
body: for 3.x, as this will be a breaking change. the main benefit of this, though making configuration of middleware awkward would be placing a middleware after say N routes, so that only N remaining routes would be influenced, allowing you to authenticate for a service etc. definitely needs some more thought, having middleware scattered throughout the app wouldn't be great

title: Add header field param access
body:
ex: "Content-Disposition: attachment; filename=tobi.jpg"

the api should be something like `req.header('content-disposition', 'filename')` returning "tobi.jpg", or "" when not present. this will be an issue if/when node decides to go with _only_ a request object etc, but will be fine for now

title: Insufficient error handling documentation
body:
We were just trying to override the 404 error handling to display our custom 404 page. While the documentation shows how to use app.error to define a custom error handler, there is nothing about the other required part: Adding a custom middleware for passing a NotFound exception after the router is finished and didn't respond.

We found our clues from /examples/error-pages/app.js .

title: move res.download logic to res.sendfile
body: these should be identical as far as error-handling goes. still not a huge fan of the double callbacks, but i fear if we make it one people may try to respond carelessly

title: res methods should be properly bound
body:
I often find myself using underscore.js (or the native bind functionality of V8) to bind methods on res, for example:

``` javascript
  send = _(res.send).bind(res)
```

This allows me to send res.send around as a callback. I see no reason that the "this" keyword shouldn't be permanently bound to the res object in all of res's methods.

```
    at next (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/http.js:204:15)
    at /usr/local/lib/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/middleware/static.js:151:11
```

This is because Express thinks `res._locals.classes` is undefined, even though it was defined by `app.helpers`!  

If I modify my code with an access to res.local (`res.local 'a',1`), like this:

```
app.helpers
    classes: ''
    content: content
    secondary_nav: false

app.get '/works/:work', getWork, (req,res)->
    res.local 'a',1
    res._locals.classes +=  new SemanticURL('/page/page:work,resource', req.url).classify()
    res.local 'secondary_nav_labels', [req.work.title] #req.work is assigned by the getWork middleware
    res.render 'work'
```

it works.

So the problem is this:
- I can only access _locals if a previous invocation of res.local or res.locals has occurred.

title: Nested mounted apps and res.redirect issue
body:
Code: https://gist.github.com/1010581

I would expect the route /subapp/subapp/redir to redirect to /subapp/subapp/test, but it redirects to /subapp/test instead.
The route /subapp/redir properly redirects to /subapp/test.

You can find the following information (modulo possible trailing slashes):

app1.route == "/"
app2.route == "/subapp"
app3.route == "/subapp"

title: Redirects lose session data?
body:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5883821/node-js-express-session-problem
1. Go to http://localhost:8003/foo
2. In the console, I can see that I have sessionID "S1" and the session contains data "B". 
3. Redirect the user to some OAuth provider such as Twitter
4. OAuth provider redirects the user back to http://localhost:8003/foo
5. In the console, I now see that I have a new sessionID "S2" and there is no session data. 

Any ideas why I'd get a new session after a redirect?

title: Sending a 304 defaults to having a body and content-type
body:
When sending a 304 (`res.send(304)`) and catching the traffic, I see the following headers:

```
Entity
  Content-Length: 12
  Content-Type: text/plain
Miscellaneous
  X-Powered-By: Express
Transport
  Connection: keep-alive
```

and the content `Not Modified`.

However, a 304 is not allowed to contain a non-empty body, and the spurious content-type causes the browser to override the (correct) content-type that the cached page contains.

Note: Sending with `res.send("", {}, 304)` solves the body problem, but shouldn't be necessary.

title: Creating an app with the exe should ln -s into local node_modules
body:
It'd be good to do this:

```
npm install -g express
express my-app
cd my-app
vim server.js
```

and be able to do `require("express")` in there, and have it work.

All that must be done to accomplish this is to have the executable do something like this:

``` javascript
fs.symlink
  ( path.resolve(__dirname, '..')
  , path.resolve(theTargetFolder, 'node_modules', 'express')
  , function (er) { ... }
  )
```

title: Wildcard routes with variable number of parameters
Updated CLI to pass in a port
body: I seem to have to manually change the port every time I build an express app.

body: OK, after a while, for the chrome problem in issue #625, i used req.socket.setTimeout(..) and it works. the broken request can now be catched. But, since express doesn't really catch this problematic request, i think the file doesn't get closed properly, care to check this? This problem causing my server to crash with the ulimit problem. my ulimit is 100000 files and the downloaders are only like 30 ip addresses.

body: It seems that a use case where an app would be mounted onto a URL with arguments in not currently supported.

title: expresso test fails on vanilla Express 2.3.9 project
body:
after generating a new express app like so:

```
express exp
```

I get the following when running tests:

```
expresso
```

Steve

title: res.sendfile() is named inconsistently
body:
Every other method of `res` which has a compound name uses lowerCamelCase: `contentType` and `clearCookie`.

`sendfile` isn't consistent, it should be `sendFile`.

title: csrf value not being generated using coffeekup as template engine
Express / jqtpl partial rendering issue
body:
Hi,

Node sure if this is the right place to discuss this, and pretty sure this isn't the right patch, but there's an issue with Express and jqtpl (possibly also other rendering engines).

When rendering partials, options.filename (which is passed to the rendering engine) is set to the filename for the containing template rather than that of the partial. I don't know enough about the API to know if this is the desired behaviour, but it's confusing jqtpl's filename-based caching.

This is the patch I'm using in my project - solves the problem for me. I'd be open to better / cleaner answers, including bouncing the issue to jqtpl.

Thanks,

Arthur

body:
```
app.param('username', /(\w[\w\d]*)/)
```

converts to /^(\w[\w\d]*)$/, exec()s and returns the first capture

title: Add support for named param mapping
body:
``` javascript
app.param('point', ...);

app.get('/pos/:a(point)..:b(point)', ....)
```

Added support for multiple view roots: define "views" options as an array, and all paths will be checked until the first one found.

title: emit events for tracing

:var(capture) matching strips /
body:
The docs show it's possible to add a capture variable in routes. However after poking around it seems like the regexes get mangled. I'm pretty sure it's this line in route.js

https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/master/lib/router/route.js#L57

The ordering of matching / vs the captures causes all the routes to get mangled because the / gets matched. 

For example from the docs:

'/user/:id(\d+)'

gets turned into

/^\/user\/(?:(d))\/?$/i

title: Issue with Layouts
body:
When rendering the the view `foo` it renders the `layout.jade` in the `reports` directory, which is expected:

```
views
    reports
        foo.jade
        layout.jade
    layout.jade
```

However when rendering out the view `bar` in it will render `layout.jade` in the `views` directory.  I guess in my mind I would expect it to grab the one in `reports` first:

```
views
    reports
        master
            bar.jade
        layout.jade
    layout.jade
```

Renaming static()
body: _static_ is a reserved keyword in JavaScript and better not used as a function name. Static resources are fetched by clients with the get request. Similar to the _get_ function for dynamic responses, _getStatic_ may be a good name for serving static resources.

title: .get() obscures .use()
body:
When adding a `.get()` route, express adds a handler to `stack` that checks all routes. When adding a middleware with `.use()` after a `.get()` route has been added, that middleware may potentially never be called.

Maybe I don't understand `.use()` properly; I assumed that it adds middleware that is supposed to run before any concrete routes added with `.get()/.post()/...`. Is that in fact the case or am I misusing express?

title: View: set options.filename for correct EJS error reporting
body:
Please, verify that it not breaks other template engines.
For EJS it helps to print file name in error stack trace correctly, very convenient for development. Otherwise, it doesn't know in which file the error was occurred, only line number.

Thanks!

title: Allow disabling the express server header
body:
I would normally not mind if others would know what server infrastructure I use, especially something as awesome as Express and node.js but I believe that this header should be possible to disable as:

```
1. it tells malicious users what infrastructure is used; since everything here is open source, this makes finding vulnerabilities easier for them

2. it does not really add value; merely send more bytes to the client
```

title: Incorrect reference to template in a comment
